The parasitoid Cotesia flavipes Cameron (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) and the predatory spined soldier bug Podisus maculiventris Say (Heteroptera: Pentatomidae) are natural enemies of the beet armyworm Spodoptera exigua HÃ¼bner (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae).
27 They can coexist in a same crop of Apium (Apiales: Apiaceae), Asparagus (Asparagales: Asparagaceae), Beta (Caryophyllales: Chenopodiaceae), Gossypium (Malvales: Malvaceae), Lactuca (Asterales: Asteraceae), Nicotiana and Solanum (Solanales: Solanaceae), and Phaseolus and Pisum (Fabales: Fabaceae), besides certain cereals, flowers, oilseeds, and weeds.
28
Cotesia flavipes adults lay eggs in the second or third instar beet armyworm
29 and larvae of this wasp pass through two instars in the caterpillar hemocoel for 12 to 16 days after oviposition depending on the environment conditions. Third instar of this parasitoid emerges from the caterpillar, pupate in cocoons, and its adults emerge in about four to eight days.
30 Predatory spined soldier bug feeds on about 90 insect species, including commercial crop pests.
31, 32 Beet armyworm is native to Asia, but it was introduced into different parts of the world where its host plants are grown.
33, 34 Smaller beet armyworm larvae feed on the leaf parenchyma, leaving the epidermis and veins intact.
